study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether sesamin could prevent the decline in exercise capacity and mitochondrial dysfunction in high-fat diet-induced diabetic mice by reducing oxidative stress.
results_summary: Sesamin prevented the diabetes-induced decrease in exercise capacity, improved mitochondrial function, and reduced oxidative stress in skeletal muscle. It also mitigated increases in blood insulin and lipid levels but did not affect plasma glucose.
population_specificity: C57BL/6J mice with high-fat diet-induced diabetes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether sesamin could protect against fluoride-induced kidney damage and apoptosis in fish by mitigating oxidative stress and inhibiting apoptotic pathways.
results_summary: Sesamin significantly reduced fluoride-induced renal damage and apoptosis in a dose-dependent manner, lowered oxidative stress markers (ROS, lipid peroxidation, GSH depletion), and inhibited caspase-3 activity and JNK signaling pathways.
population_specificity: Common carp (Cyprinus carpio) exposed to fluoride.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of sesamin supplementation on cardiovascular risk factors, oxidative stress markers, and anthropometric indices in women with rheumatoid arthritis (RA).
results_summary: Sesamin supplementation significantly reduced oxidative stress (lower MDA levels), improved antioxidant capacity (higher TAC), and increased HDL-C levels. It also led to improvements in weight, BMI, waist-to-hip ratio, body fat, systolic blood pressure, and other lipid profiles, though these changes were not significantly different between the sesamin and placebo groups.
population_specificity: Women with rheumatoid arthritis (n=44).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate sesamin's potential protective effects against cartilage degradation induced by TNF-α and OSM in a porcine cartilage explant model related to rheumatoid arthritis.
results_summary: Sesamin reduced glycosaminoglycan and collagen turnover, indicating protection against cartilage degradation in the TNF-α and OSM-induced model. The combination of TNF-α and OSM promoted more degradation than either cytokine alone, and sesamin's effects were comparable to those observed with IL-1β and OSM.
population_specificity: Porcine cartilage explants (in vitro model).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether sesamin protects against AGEs-induced β-cell dysfunction and apoptosis via its antioxidant properties.
results_summary: Sesamin treatment significantly reduced AGEs-induced β-cell dysfunction and apoptosis in both mice and MIN6 cells by decreasing ROS production, down-regulating NADPH oxidase components, and reducing NADPH oxidase activity.
population_specificity: C57BL/6J mice and MIN6 cell line.
effective_dosage: 160 mg/kg orally in mice; 50 or 100 μM in MIN6 cells.
study_duration: Four weeks in mice; 24 hours in MIN6 cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether sesamin could inhibit breast cancer cell growth and induce apoptosis in the MCF-7 cell line.
results_summary: Sesamin dose-dependently reduced cell viability, increased apoptosis, and caused sub-G1 phase arrest in the cell cycle. It also upregulated apoptotic markers (Bax, caspase-3) and cell cycle control proteins (p53, checkpoint kinase 2).
population_specificity: Human breast cancer MCF-7 cell line (in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the mechanisms by which sesamin enhances aortic nitric oxide (NO) bioactivity and reduces blood pressure in spontaneously hypertensive rats (SHRs).
results_summary: Sesamin treatment reduced systolic blood pressure, improved vascular relaxation, and enhanced NO bioactivity in SHRs by upregulating P-eNOS, suppressing eNOS uncoupling, and reducing oxidative stress. It also decreased superoxide anion production and downregulated p47phox without altering GPx or catalase activity.
population_specificity: Spontaneously hypertensive rats (SHRs)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of sesamin on mast cell-mediated allergic responses and the underlying mechanisms involved.
results_summary: Sesamin inhibited passive cutaneous anaphylaxis in rats, reduced histamine release, and suppressed pro-inflammatory cytokine production in human mast cells by modulating p38 MAPK/NF-κB signaling. The findings suggest sesamin has potential as a therapeutic agent for inflammatory allergic diseases.
population_specificity: Rats and human mast cells

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the molecular mechanisms by which sesamin (SES) induces neuroprotection in a mouse model of ischemic stroke.
results_summary: SES treatment significantly reduced infarction volume, oxidative stress markers, and inflammation while restoring antioxidant activity and attenuating harmful signaling pathways in ischemic stroke mice.
population_specificity: Adult male mice subjected to middle cerebral artery occlusion (MCAO).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of sesamin on streptozotocin-induced apoptosis in INS-1 cells and explore potential mechanisms, including NF-κB activation and oxidative stress.
results_summary: Sesamin improved cell viability and insulin secretion, reduced apoptosis, suppressed NF-κB activation, modulated Bcl-2 family proteins, and enhanced antioxidant capacity in INS-1 cells exposed to STZ.
population_specificity: INS-1 cells (pancreatic beta cell line)
study_duration: 24-hour preincubation with sesamin, followed by 12-hour STZ exposure

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether (-)-sesamin could protect against 6-OHDA-induced neurotoxicity in PC12 cells and dopaminergic neurons in a rat model of Parkinson's disease (PD).
results_summary: (-)-Sesamin reduced 6-OHDA-induced cell death in PC12 cells by modulating ERK1/2, p38MAPK, JNK1/2, and caspase-3 pathways. In rats, it increased dopaminergic neuronal survival and neurotransmitter levels, suggesting protective effects against PD-related neurodegeneration.
population_specificity: PC12 cells and 6-OHDA-lesioned rat models of Parkinson's disease.
effective_dosage: 25 µM in vitro, 30 mg/kg orally once daily in vivo.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether sesamin inhibits foam cell formation and enhances cholesterol efflux in RAW264.7 macrophages via the PPARγ-LXRα-ABCG1 pathway.
results_summary: Sesamin dose-dependently reduced cholesterol accumulation induced by oxLDL and significantly enhanced HDL-mediated cholesterol efflux. It upregulated PPARγ, LXRα, and ABCG1 mRNA levels and increased PPARγ transcriptional activity, effects inhibited by the PPARγ antagonist GW9662.
population_specificity: RAW264.7 macrophages (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate how sesamin affects the expression of heme oxygenase (HO)-1 and inducible nitric oxide synthase (iNOS) in murine macrophage cells and human embryonic kidney cells.
results_summary: Sesamin up-regulated HO-1 protein levels without affecting its mRNA, delayed the reversal of LPS-induced HO-1 protein increase, and suppressed LPS-induced iNOS protein expression and NO release. It also inhibited HO-1 ubiquitination, stabilizing the protein without affecting proteasome activity.
population_specificity: Murine macrophage cell line RAW 264.7 and human embryonic kidney (HEK) 293T cell line.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the antinociceptive and anti-inflammatory properties of sesame oil and sesamin.
results_summary: Sesamin reduced abdominal contortions, inhibited paw licking phases, increased reaction time on a hot plate, and reduced paw edema, exudate volume, and leucocyte migration, demonstrating significant antinociceptive and anti-inflammatory effects.
population_specificity: Not specified (likely animal models based on methodology).
study_duration: Acute effects measured up to 4 hours post-intervention.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether sesamin affects cancer stem-like side population (SP) cells from gallbladder cancer (GBC) by influencing their stem cell-like properties and differentiation.
results_summary: Sesamin promoted epithelial differentiation in SP cells, reduced stem cell-like characteristics (tumor-sphere formation, colony formation, invasion), weakened drug resistance, and inhibited tumor growth in vitro and in vivo. It also suppressed the NF-κB-IL-6-Stat3-Twist signaling pathway.
population_specificity: Cancer stem-like SP cells from gallbladder cancer (GBC) and nude mice xenograft models.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether (-)-sesamin could overcome multidrug resistance (MDR) mediated by ABCB1 and ABCB5 transporters and identify other molecular determinants of (-)-sesamin resistance.
results_summary: (-)-sesamin was found to inhibit ABCB1- and ABCB5-overexpressing cells with similar efficacy as their drug-sensitive counterparts, indicating it may bypass chemoresistance. Transcriptome analysis identified 23 genes correlated with (-)-sesamin sensitivity, unrelated to classical resistance mechanisms.
population_specificity: 55 cell lines from the National Cancer Institute panel.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether sesamin could enhance host defense systems and extend lifespan in Caenorhabditis elegans.
results_summary: Sesamin supplementation improved locomotion, stress resistance, and lifespan in C. elegans without affecting reproduction or growth, and it activated specific longevity-related genes (skn-1 and daf-16). However, it did not reduce oxidative damage markers like protein carbonyls and lipofuscin.
population_specificity: Nematodes (Caenorhabditis elegans)
effective_dosage: Various doses of sesamin/γ-cyclodextrin inclusion compounds (specific amounts not stated)
study_duration: From young adulthood (exact duration not specified)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize evidence on the effects of sesamin supplementation on obesity, blood pressure, and lipid profile in humans through a meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials.
results_summary: Sesamin supplementation significantly reduced total cholesterol (TC), LDL-c, and systolic blood pressure (SBP), but had no effect on HDL-c, triglycerides (TG), diastolic blood pressure (DBP), or weight. Subgroup analysis indicated that duration, study design, and participant health status influenced outcomes.
population_specificity: 212 participants across seven randomized controlled trials.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of an Ayurvedic Shatavari formulation in reducing menopausal symptoms compared to a placebo.
results_summary: The study found that Shatavari significantly reduced menopausal symptoms such as hot flashes, night sweats, insomnia, anxiety, and vaginal dryness, while improving quality of life. No significant adverse events were reported, indicating safety.
population_specificity: 70 menopausal women (35 in the test group, 35 in the placebo group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Sesamum indicum preparations, including sesamin, on managing cardiometabolic syndrome in diabetes mellitus (DM) and metabolic syndrome (MetS).
results_summary: Sesamin and other lignans in sesame oil demonstrated anti-hyperglycemic, anti-hyperlipidemic, anti-inflammatory, antioxidative, and cardioprotective effects in T2DM patients and animal models. Sesame oil as an adjuvant improved vascular reactivity, diabetic nephropathy, and anthropometry indices, with synergistic effects when combined with drugs.
population_specificity: Patients with T2DM and MetS, as well as experimental animal models with T1DM and MetS.
effective_dosage: 30-35 ml daily of sesame oil (up to 30% of total energy) or 200 mg daily of sesamin supplementation.
study_duration: 8-12 weeks for sesame oil, 8 weeks for sesamin.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antiproliferative activity of Asparagus racemosus (Shatavari) extracts on T47D breast cancer cell lines and identify potential molecular mechanisms for pharmacophore development.
results_summary: Aqueous methanol and methanol extracts of Shatavari showed excellent antiproliferative activity compared to the standard drug bazedoxifene, with rutin (a phytochemical in Shatavari) exhibiting strong binding to estrogen receptor α, suggesting potential for breast cancer treatment.
population_specificity: T47D breast cancer cell lines (in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the hepatoprotective effects of sesamin against carbon tetrachloride (CCl4)-induced liver injury in mice, focusing on oxidative stress and apoptosis.
results_summary: Sesamin significantly prevented CCl4-induced liver damage by reducing oxidative stress, suppressing apoptosis, and modulating the JNK signaling pathway. It also restored antioxidant capacity and inhibited caspase-3 activity.
population_specificity: Mice exposed to CCl4-induced liver injury.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether sesame lignans (sesamin/episesamin) combined with vitamin E (SVE) could improve subjective fatigue, sleep, physical appearance, and anti-oxidative capacity in humans.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in fatigue, sleep, and physical appearance in the SVE group, particularly in subjects aged 40 and over, along with increased anti-oxidative capacity. No adverse events were reported.
population_specificity: Subjects experiencing daily fatigue, with a subgroup analysis focusing on those aged 40 and over.
effective_dosage: 10 mg sesame lignans (sesamin/episesamin = 1/1) with 55 mg alpha-tocopherol (vitamin E).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the mechanistic effects of Shatavari on muscle adaptation responses, particularly in older women, using proteomic analysis.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in individual proteins between Shatavari and placebo groups, but pathway analysis indicated upregulation of pathways related to integrin/MAPK signaling, metabolism, cell proliferation, and others, suggesting potential benefits for muscle adaptation. Downregulated pathways included translation/amino acid metabolism and muscle contraction.
population_specificity: Older women (mean age 68.5 ± 6 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Shatavari on postmenopausal women, particularly its potential to address estradiol deficiency-related conditions like sarcopenia and osteoporosis.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding Shatavari's effects, only mentioning the study design and population.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal women (68.5 ± 6 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess Shilajit's potential protective effects against liver and kidney damage caused by osteosarcoma metastasis and its ability to enhance chemotherapy efficacy.
results_summary: Shilajit, combined with CMF chemotherapy, significantly reversed dysregulated hepatic and renal functional markers to near-normal levels and alleviated histopathological damage in liver and kidney tissues of osteosarcoma rats.
population_specificity: Osteosarcoma-induced rat model
interactions: CMF (cyclophosphamide, methotrexate, and 5-fluorouracil) chemotherapy drug cocktail

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of shilajit water extract (SWE) and its nanochitosan conjugate (SWE/NCT) on bone development and management in glucocorticoid-induced osteoporotic rats.
results_summary: SWE and SWE/NCT significantly improved serum calcium, phosphorus, osteocalcin, and calcitonin levels while reducing oxidative stress markers like hydrogen peroxide and IL-6, with SWE/NCT showing the most effectual results.
population_specificity: Adult albino female rats with glucocorticoid-induced osteoporosis.

study_goal: To investigate the neuroprotective effect of shilajit extract in experimental head trauma using a rat model.
results_summary: Shilajit extract significantly reduced red neurons and edema severity in brain tissues compared to untreated and saline-treated groups. It also increased total antioxidant capacity while decreasing total oxidant capacity and oxidative stress index in blood samples.
population_specificity: Sprague Dawley Albino strain male rats
effective_dosage: 150 mg/kg administered intraperitoneally at 1, 24, and 48 hours post-trauma

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a shilajit-based nanocarrier (SHN-Dox) for enhancing doxorubicin delivery and cytotoxicity in breast cancer cells.
results_summary: SHN-Dox demonstrated high cytotoxicity against MCF-7 and ZR-75-1 breast cancer cells, induced DNA fragmentation, increased apoptosis rates, and elevated ROS levels after 24 hours of treatment. The nanocarrier showed a sustainable release profile and potential to reduce side effects on healthy cells.
population_specificity: Breast cancer cell lines (MCF-7 and ZR-75-1).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate Shilajit's effect on cytokine and adipokine serum changes in a rat model of non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD).
results_summary: Shilajit significantly increased IL-10 and decreased IL-1β and TNF-α levels, improved insulin resistance (HOMA-IR), and modulated adiponectin and resistin levels in NAFLD rats. Both low and high doses showed comparable efficacy to pioglitazone.
population_specificity: Wistar male rats with induced NAFLD.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the in vitro effect of Mumio (Shilajit) on urinary bladder cancer cells compared to normal uroepithelial cells, focusing on cytotoxicity, cell cycle, and apoptosis.
results_summary: Mumio showed selective cytotoxicity against bladder cancer cells (T24 and 5637) compared to normal cells (SV-HUC1), inhibiting cell cycle phases (G0/G1 or S) and inducing apoptosis in a time- and concentration-dependent manner.
population_specificity: In vitro urinary bladder cancer cells (T24 and 5637) and normal uroepithelial cells (SV-HUC1).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Shilajit extract could protect against aspirin-induced gastric lesions in rats, comparing its effects to omeprazole.
results_summary: Shilajit significantly reduced gastric lesion size and number, comparable to omeprazole, and increased oxidative stress enzyme levels (except malondialdehyde), indicating protective effects against aspirin-induced damage.
population_specificity: Male rats (45 total, divided into five groups).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether Shilajit possesses antiepileptic and antipsychotic activities in rodent models.
results_summary: Shilajit pretreatment significantly inhibited seizures induced by MES, INH, and PTZ in a dose-dependent manner and increased brain GABA levels. It also reduced apomorphine-induced climbing and stereotyped behaviors, suggesting potential antipsychotic effects.
population_specificity: Rodents (rats and mice)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of Shilajit on liver damage caused by non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) in a rat model.
results_summary: Shilajit treatment significantly reduced liver damage markers (AST, ALT, TG, TC, LDL, glucose, liver weight, and steatosis), increased HDL, and restored antioxidant/oxidant balance compared to the control group. It also improved histopathological liver changes induced by a high-fat diet.
population_specificity: Male Wistar rats with induced NAFLD via a high-fat diet.
effective_dosage: 150 mg/kg (low dose) and 250 mg/kg (high dose) Shilajit.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of purified Shilajit on male androgenic hormones, including testosterone, in healthy volunteers.
results_summary: Shilajit significantly increased total testosterone, free testosterone, and DHEAS levels compared to placebo, while maintaining gonadotropic hormone (LH and FSH) levels.
population_specificity: Healthy volunteers aged 45–55 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether Shilajit could prevent radiation-induced ovarian damage in rats by examining its effects on follicle counts and apoptotic markers.
results_summary: Shilajit significantly preserved follicle counts and reduced expression of apoptotic markers (p53, Bax, caspase 3) in irradiated rats compared to the radiation-only group, suggesting protective effects against ovarian damage.
population_specificity: Female Wistar albino rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the neuroprotective and functional effects of Andean Shilajit (AnSh) fractions on neuronal processes and tau aggregation in Alzheimer's disease models.
results_summary: AnSh fractions increased the number and length of neuronal processes in a dose-dependent manner, inhibited tau self-aggregation after 10 days, and identified two candidate molecules in the M3 fraction.
population_specificity: Primary cultures of rat hippocampal neurons and mouse neuroblastoma cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of shilajit and complex B vitamins in preventing Alzheimer's disease (AD).
results_summary: The study suggests that shilajit and its active component fulvic acid, as well as a combination with B complex vitamins, may have potential as a nutraceutical for AD prevention, supported by biological studies and clinical trial data in mild AD patients.
population_specificity: Patients with mild Alzheimer's disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the cardioprotective effects of Shilajit (mumie) pre-treatment in rats subjected to myocardial injury induced by isoproterenol.
results_summary: Shilajit maintained cardiac function parameters, reduced serum cardiac troponin I, and lessened cardiac lesion severity in injured rats, suggesting cardioprotective effects. However, it had no significant impact on antioxidant capacity or lipid peroxidation.
population_specificity: Rats (with and without induced myocardial injury)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of standardized Shilajit on chronic fatigue syndrome (CFS) in rats, focusing on mitochondrial bioenergetics and HPA axis activity.
results_summary: Shilajit reversed CFS-induced behavioral symptoms, attenuated anxiety, modulated HPA axis activity, and preserved mitochondrial function by stabilizing enzyme activities and reducing oxidative stress.
population_specificity: Rat model of chronic fatigue syndrome.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and spermatogenic activity of processed Shilajit (PS) in oligospermic patients.
results_summary: PS significantly improved sperm count, motility, and morphology while reducing oxidative stress markers and increasing serum testosterone and FSH levels, with no adverse effects on hepatic or renal function.
population_specificity: 35 oligospermic male patients (total sperm count <20 million/ml semen).
effective_dosage: 100 mg capsule twice daily after major meals.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore Shilajit's potential benefits, particularly its cognitive effects and possible applications in Alzheimer's therapy, focusing on fulvic acid's role in blocking tau self-aggregation.
results_summary: Shilajit is described as a safe and potent dietary supplement with potential cognitive benefits, including preventing cognitive disorders associated with aging. Fulvic acid, its main active component, shows promise in blocking tau self-aggregation, suggesting therapeutic potential for Alzheimer's disease.
population_specificity: Not specified (general human health implications).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the physical and chemical properties of Shilajit extracts and their effects on the complement system, particularly focusing on fulvic acid content.
results_summary: Shilajit fractions exhibited dose-dependent complement-fixing activity in vitro, with high potency, and a strong correlation was found between this activity and carboxylic group content. The study suggests that these properties may explain part of Shilajit's therapeutic benefits.
population_specificity: In vitro study (no human or animal subjects specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Shilajit's memory-enhancing effects are due to neurochemical alterations in specific neurotransmitter systems, particularly cholinergic pathways.
results_summary: Shilajit reduced acetylcholinesterase activity in basal forebrain nuclei and increased M1-muscarinic receptor binding in certain brain regions, suggesting enhanced cholinergic signaling. It did not affect GABAergic or glutamatergic receptor subtypes.
population_specificity: Adult male Wistar rats
effective_dosage: 40 mg/kg body weight, administered intraperitoneally daily

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess Shilajit's effectiveness in treating cadmium-induced male infertility in mice by evaluating its impact on reproductive organ weights, sperm production, enzyme activity, and fertility outcomes.
results_summary: Shilajit improved reproductive organ weights, sperm production, testosterone levels, and restored spermatogenesis in cadmium-treated mice. It also enhanced sperm motility, concentration, and overall fertility, including litter size.
population_specificity: Adult (12-14 week) Swiss male mice with cadmium-induced infertility.
effective_dosage: 50 mg, 100 mg, and 200 mg/kg body weight, administered orally daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Shirazi thyme (Zataria multiflora Boiss.) supplementation on nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) and related insulin resistance.
results_summary: Shirazi thyme supplementation significantly reduced serum insulin levels and improved insulin resistance in NAFLD patients compared to placebo, with no significant changes in liver enzymes or lipid profiles.
population_specificity: 85 patients with NAFLD.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review experimental and clinical studies on the effects of Z. multiflora (Shirazi thyme) on respiratory, allergic, and immunologic disorders.
results_summary: The study found that Z. multiflora extracts exhibited bronchodilatory, antioxidant, immunomodulatory, and anti-inflammatory effects, showing potential in treating respiratory disorders like asthma, COPD, lung infections, and lung cancer. Clinical studies supported its preventive and therapeutic benefits.
population_specificity: Experimental animal models and clinical study participants (specific details not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to chemically characterize Shivlingi seed oil (SLSO) and evaluate its effects on fertility and fecundity in a zebrafish model of induced infertility.
results_summary: SLSO, rich in linoleic and linolenic acids, improved fertility and fecundity in both male and female zebrafish, restoring ovarian anatomy and increasing sperm counts and motility. Its effects were comparable to Letrozole, a standard infertility treatment.
population_specificity: Zebrafish with N-ethyl-N-nitrosourea-induced infertility.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the long-term impact of silicon nanoparticles (SiNPs) exposure on cardiac hypertrophy and its underlying mechanisms.
results_summary: SiNPs exposure induced significant cardiac hypertrophic remodeling, systolic and diastolic dysfunction, mitochondrial damage, and activation of pyroptosis pathways. Hypertrophy decreased after exposure cessation, with no further pyroptosis-mediated damage observed.
population_specificity: Rats
effective_dosage: Intratracheal instillations once a week for six months (24 doses total)
study_duration: Six months of exposure followed by a six-month recovery period

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop mesoporous silica-encapsulated colloidal Ag nanoaggregates (AgNAs@m-SiO2) to enhance the long-term stability and performance of SERS substrates for environmental sensing applications.
results_summary: The AgNAs@m-SiO2 substrate demonstrated superior structural stability, retaining 91.8% of its initial SERS signal after 50 min of ultrasonic treatment and 84.3% after 70 days of storage, significantly outperforming uncoated controls. It also enabled ultra-sensitive detection of contaminants in real environmental matrices, validating its suitability for field applications.
population_specificity: Environmental sensing applications (river and seawater samples)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the ethnopharmacology, pharmacology, toxicology, modern pharmaceutical uses, and phytochemistry of Zataria multiflora (Shirazi thyme) and identify gaps in knowledge.
results_summary: Shirazi thyme exhibits antimicrobial, antioxidative, anti-inflammatory, spasmolytic, and anti-nociceptive properties, with its oil containing high levels of thymol and carvacrol. The study highlights its traditional uses and modern pharmacological potential but notes a lack of comprehensive phytochemical analysis in previous research.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of existing literature)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the antimicrobial photodynamic, sonodynamic, and combined effects of IR780 iodide-loaded mesoporous silica nanoparticles against Pseudomonas aeruginosa and multi-drug-resistant Pseudomonas aeruginosa.
results_summary: Combined photodynamic and sonodynamic therapy resulted in a 44-45% reduction in bacterial cell viability for both strains, outperforming individual therapies (18-31% reduction). The killing effect was attributed to singlet oxygen generation, with no photothermal involvement.
population_specificity: Pseudomonas aeruginosa (standard and multi-drug-resistant strains)
effective_dosage: Laser irradiation (785 nm, 500 mW/cm², 5 min); Ultrasound irradiation (1 MHz, 1.5 W/cm², 50% duty cycle, 3 min)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether fumed silica could effectively replace carbon black as a filler in rubber compounding, improving hardness, tensile strength, and wet skid performance while addressing mixing challenges.
results_summary: The study found that fumed silica improved tread rubber hardness by 20% and 300% tensile modulus by 14%, reduced rolling resistance, and enhanced wet skid performance. A hydration-ball milling process improved silica dispersion, tensile strength, and dynamic performance while minimizing dust and mixing time.
population_specificity: Not specified (industrial/material science context)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of SIRPα/CD47 signaling in silicosis progression and its potential as a therapeutic target.
results_summary: The study found that blocking SIRPα/CD47 signaling reduced lung injury, decreased collagen deposition, and improved pulmonary function in a silicosis mouse model. It also countered silica-induced suppression of macrophage phagocytosis and promoted M1 polarization.
population_specificity: Silicosis mouse model and silicosis patients (human peripheral blood analysis).
effective_dosage: Not specified (RRx-001 used as a blocker, but dosage not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if silica particles loaded with IGF-1 in a composite hydrogel could achieve sustained drug release and promote osteogenic differentiation for chronic osteomyelitis treatment.
results_summary: The hydrogel with silica particles demonstrated sustained release of IGF-1 over 144 hours, antibacterial effects against S. aureus, excellent biocompatibility, and the ability to induce osteogenic differentiation in bone marrow stem cells.
population_specificity: Bone marrow stem cells and bacterial cultures (S. aureus) in a laboratory setting.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a novel prodrug encapsulated in soluble colloidal silica nanoparticles for targeted delivery to treat malignant melanoma.
results_summary: The study demonstrated a 50% reduction in tumor size after three intravenous treatments, highlighting the potential of silica nanoparticles for targeted drug delivery in melanoma therapy.
population_specificity: Preclinical models of malignant melanoma (cell culture and animal models).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop an acidity-responsive silica-coated magnetite nanoparticle-based nanocarrier for targeted delivery and controlled release of doxorubicin in breast cancer treatment.
results_summary: The study demonstrated successful DOX loading (433.147 mg/g) and acid-sensitive release, with significant cytotoxicity against MCF-7 breast cancer cells, indicating effective targeted delivery and controlled release.
population_specificity: MCF-7 breast cancer cells (in vitro).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of mesoporous silica nanoparticles (MSNs) loaded with levofloxacin and coated with a gelatin shell containing N-acetylcysteine for treating E. coli biofilm-related infections.
results_summary: The study found that the MSN-based nanoformulation achieved a 99.8% reduction in mature E. coli biofilms by sequentially releasing N-acetylcysteine to disrupt the biofilm and levofloxacin for sustained antimicrobial action. Preliminary in vitro studies indicated good biocompatibility of the nanosystems.
population_specificity: In vitro study involving E. coli biofilms and preosteoblastic cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antibacterial activity and Cd (II) ion removal efficiency of green-synthesized silver nanoparticles modified with silica and dopamine.
results_summary: The study found that AgNPs@TEOS@DA exhibited high antibacterial activity and efficient Cd (II) ion removal, with optimal adsorption at pH 6.0 and a 15-minute incubation time. The nanosorbent demonstrated concentration-dependent adsorption behavior and adhered to green chemistry principles.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study focusing on aqueous solutions and bacterial inhibition).
effective_dosage: Not specified (study focused on adsorption efficiency rather than dosage).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of hollow mesoporous silica nanoparticles (HA-SS-HMS) for targeted co-delivery of Vincristine and Gemcitabine in pancreatic cancer cells.
results_summary: The study found that VC/GT@HA-SS-HMS exhibited regulated, pH-responsive drug release, superior synergistic cytotoxicity, and increased apoptotic rates in PANC-1 pancreatic cancer cells compared to free drugs or single-drug-loaded nanoparticles. Fluorescence imaging confirmed effective targeting and dispersion in CD44(+) PANC-1 cells.
population_specificity: CD44(+) PANC-1 pancreatic cancer cell line.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether mesoporous silica nanoparticles (MSNs), specifically SBA-15, could improve the dissolution rate, bioavailability, and transdermal delivery of Carvedilol (CRV) for pediatric use.
results_summary: CRV-loaded SBA-15 showed superior dissolution (72.42% efficiency) and enhanced skin permeation (714.49 ± 38.49 µg/cm² after 24h) compared to pure CRV, demonstrating improved solubility and bioavailability. The amorphous transformation and large pore diameter of SBA-15 contributed to these effects.
population_specificity: Pediatric patients (implied, not explicitly stated).
effective_dosage: Not specified (three saturation levels tested, but exact amounts not provided).
study_duration: Not specified (24h ex vivo skin permeation study mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how silica exposure affects lung microbiota and pulmonary fibrosis progression via the PI3K/AKT pathway.
results_summary: Silica exposure caused lung microbiota dysbiosis and cellular senescence, driven by LPS production, which activated the PI3K/AKT pathway and promoted pulmonary fibrosis. The study suggests targeting ATⅡ senescence could mitigate silica-induced fibrosis.
population_specificity: C57BL/6 J mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and evaluate a novel LVM-loaded mesoporous silica nanoparticle formulation (ApoE3@LVM-Chito-MSN) for enhanced brain-targeting in treating brain tumor-related epilepsy.
results_summary: The study found that ApoE3@LVM-Chito-MSN demonstrated a 3-fold increase in brain uptake compared to LVM solution, with reduced distribution to other organs. Safety assessments, including hemolysis and histological studies, indicated no significant adverse effects.
population_specificity: Patients with brain tumor-related epilepsy (preclinical study, likely animal models).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether hucMSC-EVs, particularly those engineered with miR-148a-3p, could effectively mitigate silica-induced pulmonary fibrosis in mice.
results_summary: HucMSC-EVs reduced fibrotic changes in mouse lung tissues, with miR-148a-3p-overexpressed EVs showing enhanced antifibrotic effects. The mechanism involved miR-148a-3p targeting Hsp90b1 to blunt β-catenin signaling in fibroblasts.
population_specificity: Silica-exposed mice with induced pulmonary fibrosis.
study_duration: Administered from day 28 to day 56 after silica exposure (28 days).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of mesoporous silica nanoparticles (MSNs) as a drug delivery system to combat multidrug resistance (MDR) in tumor treatment.
results_summary: The study found that MSNs, with their high surface area, adjustable pore sizes, and functionalization capabilities, serve as effective carriers for delivering chemotherapeutics and siRNAs to reverse resistance pathways. The paper highlights innovative methods for intranuclear delivery to overcome efflux barriers and improve combination therapy effectiveness.
population_specificity: Not specified (general focus on tumor treatment and MDR).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a silica-based dual-drug delivery system (FMCC) for treating neuropathic pain by reducing oxidative stress and inflammation.
results_summary: FMCC showed good biocompatibility, effectively reversed oxidative stress and inflammation in vitro, and provided sustained relief of neuropathic pain in mice with chronic constriction injury.
population_specificity: BV2 cells (in vitro) and mice with chronic constriction injury (in vivo).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether heat and steam treatments could enhance the thermal stability of FAU zeolites.
results_summary: The optimal steam treatment with 1% humidity retained 69% relative crystallinity after exposure to 1150 °C for 24 hours, reducing crystallinity loss by half compared to untreated samples. This method produced zeolites with exceptional thermal stability.
population_specificity: Not specified (material science study, not human or animal subjects).
effective_dosage: Not applicable (study involved material treatment conditions, not human dosage).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the cardiovascular toxicity mechanisms of silica nanoparticles (SiNPs) of different sizes (50 nm, 300 nm, and 1 μm) in mice and HL-1 cells.
results_summary: Exposure to SiNPs caused size-dependent mitochondrial damage and mitophagy, with 50 nm SiNPs blocking autophagy flux, leading to excessive mtDNA accumulation and exacerbating pyroptosis via the cGAS-STING pathway. Mice exposed to SiNPs showed significant weight loss, increased heart volume, and myocardial fiber cross-sectional area.
population_specificity: C57/BL6 mice and HL-1 cells.
effective_dosage: Not specified (different-sized SiNPs: 50 nm, 300 nm, and 1 μm).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether click chemistry-functionalized mesoporous silica (SiO2-Mal) nanotraps could effectively capture active metabolites of thienopyridine antiplatelet drugs (clopidogrel and prasugrel) and restore hemostasis.
results_summary: The study found that SiO2-Mal nanotraps successfully captured the active metabolites of antiplatelet drugs, reversing their effects and restoring hemostasis in mouse, rabbit, and pig models. The results suggest potential clinical application as a reversal agent for thienopyridine antiplatelet drugs.
population_specificity: Animal models (mice, rabbits, pigs)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether loading rifampin into mesoporous silica nanoparticles (MSNs) could improve the mechanical properties, drug release, and antibacterial activity of bone cement while maintaining cellular viability.
results_summary: Loading rifampin into MSNs improved compressive strength by 57.52%, enhanced antibacterial activity (15.44% and 11.8% greater inhibition zones for S. aureus and CoNS, respectively), and increased rifampin washout by 33.2-fold over 5 weeks compared to free rifampin. Cellular viability remained acceptable.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro or preclinical study implied).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of amorphous silica-coated iron oxide nanocrystals (IONCs) in catalyzing the degradation of organic compounds in water under microwave irradiation.
results_summary: The study found that amorphous silica-coated IONCs effectively catalyzed the degradation of model organic compounds (methyl orange and benzoic acid) through a thermally enhanced Fenton-type process, with high performance and repeatability over five cycles without nanocrystal deterioration or metal leaching.
population_specificity: Not applicable (in vitro study using water and wastewater treatment models).
effective_dosage: Not specified (concentrations of nanocrystals, pH, and H2O2 were optimized but exact dosages not detailed).
study_duration: Not specified (study evaluated performance over five cycles but exact duration not mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether amino-functionalized mesoporous silica (MS-NH2) could effectively adsorb warfarin and serve as an antidote for warfarin toxicity.
results_summary: MS-NH2 demonstrated high adsorption capacity for warfarin (1666 mg/g) and significantly improved INR and prothrombin time in warfarin-overdosed mice, while also reducing biomarkers of tissue damage.
population_specificity: Mice (animal model)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop mesoporous silica nanoparticle (MSN)-based nanocarriers capable of co-transporting drugs and nucleic acids for targeted delivery to liver cancer cells.
results_summary: The hybrid MSN-glycopolymer nanosystems showed 280-fold higher transfection activity in liver cancer cells compared to bare MSN particles and effectively mediated a combined antitumor strategy involving suicide gene therapy and chemotherapy.
population_specificity: Liver cancer cells (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and evaluate a silica-based nanomedicine platform (OM-CeMeso) for treating inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) by enhancing stability, ROS scavenging, and gut microbiota restoration.
results_summary: The silica-based nanomaterial demonstrated improved stability in a murine IBD model, enhanced ROS scavenging due to cerium oxide, and increased beneficial gut microbiota diversity and abundance, leading to significant symptom alleviation without toxicity.
population_specificity: Murine (mouse) model of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of mesoporous silica nanoparticles (MSNs) as a drug delivery system for managing hepatic diseases, focusing on their physicochemical properties, targeting mechanisms, and therapeutic applications.
results_summary: The study found that MSNs exhibit favorable physicochemical properties for controlled drug delivery, can be tailored for passive liver targeting, and show promise in addressing liver pathologies like tumors and inflammation through multifunctional designs and intelligent release modes.
population_specificity: Not specified (theoretical and preclinical focus).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a stimuli-responsive nanosystem using mesoporous silica nanoparticles for co-delivering 5-fluorouracil and everolimus to enhance synergistic anticancer effects and controlled drug release.
results_summary: The silica-based nanosystem demonstrated high cellular uptake, pH-sensitive drug release, and significant increases in cancer cell death and apoptosis. It also reduced tumor size and lung metastasis in mice compared to monotherapy and control groups.
population_specificity: Balb/C mice with 4T1 breast cancer cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether BI 1015550, a PDE4B inhibitor, could improve lung fibrosis and inflammation in silica-induced silicosis and LPS-induced acute lung injury mouse models.
results_summary: BI 1015550 significantly improved lung fibrosis and inflammation in a silica-induced silicosis mouse model and alleviated lung inflammation in an LPS-induced acute lung injury mouse model, likely via cAMP-related signaling pathways.
population_specificity: Silica-induced silicosis and LPS-induced acute lung injury mouse models.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of folic acid and chitosan-functionalized mesoporous silica nanoparticles (MSN-EPI@CS-FA) as a drug delivery system for epirubicin in inhibiting cancer cell growth.
results_summary: The functionalized MSNs showed high drug loading efficiency (79.49%) and superior efficacy in inhibiting MCF-7 cells and 4T1 tumors in mice, inducing apoptosis via mitochondrial pathways and altering oxidative stress markers. The nanoparticles also demonstrated targeted tumor delivery without significant accumulation in the liver or spleen.
population_specificity: MCF-7 cell line and mice bearing 4T1 breast tumors.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the microshear bond strength between resin cement and different translucent zirconias after surface treatments involving tribochemical silica coating (CoJet) and thermal cycling.
results_summary: Tribochemical silica coating (CoJet) promoted higher bond strength compared to aluminum oxide air abrasion, but thermal cycling negatively affected bond strength across all zirconias. 3Y-TZP showed greater bond strength than translucent zirconias.
population_specificity: Zirconia specimens (3Y-PSZ, 4Y-PSZ, 5Y-PSZ, and 3Y-TZP as control)
effective_dosage: Not applicable (surface treatment, not oral consumption)
study_duration: Testing occurred after 7 days in distilled water or after aging (30 days and 10,000 thermal cycles).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether mesoporous silica nanoparticles (MRL) modified with RGD and loaded with LL-37 could effectively treat implant-related infections by reducing biofilm formation and macrophage pyroptosis while enhancing antimicrobial activity.
results_summary: The study found that MRL preserved LL-37's antimicrobial and immunomodulatory effects while significantly reducing macrophage pyroptosis, improving immune function, and preventing bacterial resistance. In vitro and in vivo experiments supported these findings.
population_specificity: Not specified (likely preclinical models, given the in vitro and in vivo focus).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of virus-like mesoporous silica nanoparticles (MSN) as a delivery platform for repurposed metformin in a topical multi-stimuli responsive system for melanoma treatment.
results_summary: MTF-MSN demonstrated significant antiproliferative activity against melanoma A375 cells, with lower IC50 values compared to free MTF, and showed sustained, pH-sensitive release. In vivo studies revealed enhanced anti-cancer efficacy, evidenced by elevated caspase-3 and NF-1 levels and suppressed angiogenesis markers.
population_specificity: Melanoma A375 cells and an in vivo melanoma model.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of Haizao Yuhu Decoction (HYD) on silica-induced lung injury and the underlying mechanisms, focusing on the TGF-β1/Smad pathway and epithelial-mesenchymal transition (EMT).
results_summary: HYD significantly reduced silica-induced lung injury, inflammation, and collagen deposition by inhibiting the TGF-β1/Smad pathway and EMT. Bioactive constituents (glycitein, diosmetin, limonin) also suppressed TGF-β1-induced cell proliferation and migration.
population_specificity: Silica-induced lung injury mouse model and TGF-β1-induced alveolar epithelial cell model (MLE12 cells).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of silica-based nano-PROTACs (SiPROTACs) in targeting and degrading EGFR for the treatment of non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC).
results_summary: SiPROTACs demonstrated efficient EGFR degradation at low concentrations (50 nM) in HCC-827 and PC-9 cell lines and showed significant anti-tumor effects in HCC-827 xenograft mice without noticeable side effects. The nanoparticles accumulated at tumor sites for at least 48 hours.
population_specificity: HCC-827 and PC-9 cell lines, HCC-827 xenograft tumor-bearing mice.
effective_dosage: 50 nM in cell lines (specific dosage in mice not mentioned).
study_duration: Tumor accumulation observed for at least 48 hours (full intervention duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of pH-sensitive hollow mesoporous silica nanoparticles (PLACS NPs) for targeted delivery of the CRISPR/dCas9-SAM system in bladder cancer treatment.
results_summary: PLACS NPs demonstrated good stability, high plasmid loading capacity, and superior lysosomal escape capability, significantly enhancing transfection efficiency and activating four target genes to inhibit bladder cancer cell proliferation and migration while promoting apoptosis. In vivo, they achieved efficient gene editing at tumor sites without significant liver targeting or major organ toxicity.
population_specificity: Bladder cancer cells and in vivo models.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the epidemiology, occupational risks, regulatory gaps, diagnostic evaluation, and clinical challenges associated with engineered stone (ES) dust exposure, particularly focusing on respirable crystalline silica (RCS).
results_summary: The study found that ES dust exposure leads to accelerated silicosis, diagnosed after 7-19 years of exposure, with high morbidity and mortality rates, including lung transplantation and death. Industrial hygiene data showed that despite engineering controls, RCS exposure frequently exceeds safe levels, highlighting significant occupational risks.
population_specificity: Workers fabricating engineered stone countertops, particularly young individuals (median age 33-55 years) from marginalized or immigrant communities.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to synthesize and evaluate Chitosan Magnetite Silica (CMS) capsules for effective removal of anionic dyes (RB-19 and RY-17) from solutions.
results_summary: The CMS capsules demonstrated high adsorption capacities (455.86 mg g-1 for RB-19 and 344.06 mg g-1 for RY-17) with over 95% removal efficacy at optimal conditions (50 mg dose, 60 min, pH 3.0). The capsules were reusable for six adsorption-desorption cycles and exhibited eco-friendly properties with low waste generation.
population_specificity: Not applicable (in vitro study using synthetic dye solutions).
effective_dosage: 50 mg of CMS capsules per batch.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of mesoporous silica (SBA-16) and reduced graphene oxide (rGO) as substrates for Fe3O4 nanoparticles in degrading synthetic acid blue 40 dye (AB40) via Fenton catalytic reactions.
results_summary: The study found that Fe3O4/SBA-16 and Fe3O4/rGO composites enhanced the stability and catalytic efficiency of Fe3O4 nanoparticles, achieving full decolorization of AB40 under optimal conditions (pH 3, 35°C, 60 min). The catalysts demonstrated high reusability (>95% efficiency) and stability over four degradation cycles.
population_specificity: Synthetic dye (AB40) in wastewater treatment.
effective_dosage: Catalyst dose = 1 g/L, initial dye concentration = 50 mg/L, [H2O2] = 15 mmol/L.
study_duration: 60 minutes per cycle, with four cycles conducted.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore mesoporous silica (mSiO2) as a framework for confining metal nanoparticles to enhance sustainability in water management and environmental applications.
results_summary: The study found that nanoconfinement within mSiO2 structures offers unique opportunities for environmental applications, such as tandem catalysis, SERS sensing, and visible-light-driven water treatment, while addressing challenges of functionality loss and operational costs.
population_specificity: Not specified (focused on environmental and industrial applications, not human subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop an extended-release (XR) formulation using chitosan-embedded silica particles (CHESS) to improve intravitreal drug delivery for retinal vascular diseases.
results_summary: The study demonstrated that CHESS successfully controlled drug release rates in vitro, improved intravitreal mobility, and showed good tolerability with low toxicity on ARPE-19 cells. The formulation enabled high drug loads (>20%) for small molecules and peptides, facilitating stable vitreous depots.
population_specificity: Preclinical (in vitro and likely animal models, though not explicitly stated).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop an improved photocatalyst using CdS, TiO2, and MCM-41 for efficient degradation of Methylene Blue (MB) in wastewater.
results_summary: The study found that a 15% w/w loading of CdS/TiO2/MCM-41 (CTM) achieved 45.6% MB degradation in 30 minutes under neutral pH, with 63% TOC reduction in 90 minutes, indicating effective mineralization. Response surface methodology identified key factors (pH, airflow, photocatalyst concentration) enhancing degradation performance.
population_specificity: Not applicable (in vitro study on pollutant degradation).
effective_dosage: 15% w/w loading of CdS/TiO2 on MCM-41.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether ammonia solution pretreatment of a SiO2 carrier could enhance the catalytic activity of Pd/SiO2 for formaldehyde (HCHO) oxidation at ambient temperature.
results_summary: The study found that ammonia solution pretreatment of SiO2 increased surface defects, improving Pd nanoparticle dispersion and oxygen vacancy formation, which significantly enhanced HCHO oxidation efficiency (near-complete conversion at 25°C compared to 5% without pretreatment).
population_specificity: Not applicable (in vitro catalytic study).
effective_dosage: Not specified (catalyst preparation details provided but not dosage in traditional supplement terms).
study_duration: Not specified (experimental conditions described, but no explicit duration mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of NLRP3 inflammasome, glycolysis, and histone lactylation in silica-induced epithelial-mesenchymal transition (EMT) in human bronchial epithelial cells.
results_summary: Silica exposure activated NLRP3 inflammasome, enhanced glycolysis and histone lactylation, and induced EMT. Inhibition of NLRP3 inflammasome, IL-1 receptor blockade, or lactate suppression mitigated these effects, revealing a key inflammation-glycolysis-lactylation cascade in silica-induced pulmonary fibrosis.
population_specificity: Human bronchial epithelial cells (16HBE).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of chitosan-silica nanoparticle (CTS-SiNPs) coating on the postharvest quality and flavor profile of hardy kiwifruits during storage.
results_summary: The CTS-SiNPs coating showed superior preservation effects compared to chitosan alone, delaying ripening and volatile accumulation while enhancing "herbal" odor and reducing "sweet" and "floral" odors in kiwifruits.
population_specificity: Hardy kiwifruits stored at 25°C and 4°C.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether mesoporous silica nanomaterials (MSN) combined with a lipoprotein complex (BAMLET) could re-sensitize methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) to aminoglycoside antibiotics and improve bioavailability and antioxidant capacity when loaded with curcumin.
results_summary: The study found that BAMLET@MSN conjugates (BMSN) disrupted bacterial cell membranes, inhibited biofilm formation, and restored antibiotic efficacy in MRSA. Transcriptomic analysis indicated BMSN interfered with bacterial metabolic pathways, enhancing antibiotic entry and bactericidal effects.
population_specificity: Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) bacteria.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether silica treatment could inhibit sulfide oxidation in pyritic waste rock and prevent acid rock drainage (ARD) formation.
results_summary: Silica treatment improved leachate quality by suppressing sulfur and metal release, maintained circumneutral pH, and formed a stable SiO2 layer on waste rock. H2O2 pre-oxidation indirectly oxidized sulfides, while excess silicate solution at alkaline pH mobilized metal ions.
population_specificity: Pyritic waste rock from an operating Cu mine in Sweden.
effective_dosage: Not specified (alkaline silicate solution applied without pH buffer/adjuster).
study_duration: 11 weeks of leaching before treatment, followed by up to 10 weeks of post-treatment exposure.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop mesoporous silica particles for water remediation, specifically to adsorb heavy metal ions like Pb(II).
results_summary: The study found that mesoporous silica particles with hexagonal pore ordering effectively adsorbed Pb(II) with a high sorption capacity of 110 mg/g. Template removal via calcination preserved pore structure better than acidified ethanol treatment.
population_specificity: Not applicable (in vitro study).
effective_dosage: Not specified (batch experiments at pH 5 and 4 h contact time).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and evaluate methods for controlling the morphology and size of hollow polymer@silica microspheres, comparing the layer-by-layer (LBL) and sol-gel methods.
results_summary: The study found that hollow polymer@silica microspheres prepared via the sol-gel method had a uniform and dense inorganic shell, better compression resistance, and good opacity, remaining intact at high pressure (16,000 psi) and providing coatings with low transmittance (<35.1%). The LBL method allowed adjustable shell thickness but resulted in less uniform structures.
population_specificity: Not applicable (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the catalytic activity of SiO2-AuNP aerogels and the effect of PVP stabilization on gold nanoparticle size and plasmon resonance properties.
results_summary: The study found that SiO2-AuNP aerogels synthesized with PVP maintained smaller gold nanoparticles, while those without PVP formed larger aggregates, altering plasmon resonance color. Thermal treatment reversed this effect, breaking clusters into individual nanoparticles, and both aerogel types demonstrated catalytic activity in reducing 4-nitrophenol.
population_specificity: Not applicable (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the burden, mechanisms, and potential treatments for silicosis and related pulmonary disorders caused by crystalline silica exposure.
results_summary: The study highlights the severe health impacts of silica exposure, including silicosis, lung cancer, and other pulmonary diseases, and discusses emerging nanoparticle-based therapeutic approaches showing promise in preclinical models.
population_specificity: Occupational workers exposed to respirable crystalline silica dust globally.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a sulfonated reverse osmosis (RO) membrane resistant to silica scaling while maintaining high water permeance and salt rejection.
results_summary: The sulfonated RO membrane (SLRO) significantly reduced silica scaling rates under acidic, neutral, and alkaline conditions, improved water permeance (3.3 L m-2 h-1 bar-1), and maintained high NaCl rejection (99.2%). The enhanced performance was attributed to increased surface charge density and reduced coordination capacity.
population_specificity: Industrial wastewater treatment systems (in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the synthesis techniques and applications of silica aerogels in environmental and energy conservation technologies.
results_summary: The study found that silica aerogels, particularly when combined with phase change materials or used in supercapacitors, show significant potential for energy conservation. The synergistic effects of silica and graphene aerogels further broaden their applications.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of existing research)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the performance of CuOx/MgO-SiO2 catalysts in degrading Sulfamethoxazole (SMX) in antibiotic wastewater via catalytic ozonation.
results_summary: The CuOx/MgO-SiO2 catalyst achieved 87.92% SMX removal efficiency under optimal conditions, significantly outperforming ozonation alone. Active species (·OH, ·O2-, 1O2) and valence cycling between Cu2+/Cu+ and Mg2+/Mg were key to degradation, and the treated wastewater showed reduced toxicity.
population_specificity: Antibiotic wastewater (not human or animal subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether silica nanoparticles derived from melon seed husk extract (MSHE) could mitigate testicular toxicity induced by heavy metals (Ni and Al) in male albino rats.
results_summary: MSHE co-administration increased plasma gonadotropin hormones (FSH, LH, testosterone) and reduced prolactin levels, while also improving testis architecture and antioxidant activity. MSHE alone showed beneficial hormonal effects compared to metal-exposed groups.
population_specificity: Male albino rats exposed to heavy metals (Ni, Al, or a mixture).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and evaluate mesoporous yolk-shell silica spheres (YS-x) as catalysts for formic acid dehydrogenation to generate hydrogen.
results_summary: The optimal catalyst, Pd-YS-6-NH2, demonstrated superior dehydrogenation performance with a high turnover frequency (4508 h-1) and excellent stability, maintaining 100% formic acid conversion after five cycles. The performance was attributed to the yolk-shell structure, amine groups, and highly dispersed ultrasmall Pd nanoparticles (1.5 nm).
population_specificity: Not applicable (in vitro/catalytic study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether the SiO2@KH550/FC-A nano-composite system could effectively modify the hydrophobicity of tight sandstone reservoirs to reduce aqueous phase trapping damage and improve oil and gas production capacity.
results_summary: The SiO2@KH550/FC-A composite system successfully increased the contact angle of hydrophilic surfaces from ~20° to 130°, demonstrating strong hydrophobicity and stability. Core experiments showed significant reductions in brine imbibition (from 2.6 mL to 0.5 mL) and improved permeability recovery (88.4%), indicating enhanced liquid phase flowback ability.
population_specificity: Tight sandstone reservoir core samples

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether selenium-quantum-dot-loaded porous silica nanospheres (Se@PSN) could effectively mitigate ferroptosis and mitochondrial dysfunction in myocardial ischemia-reperfusion (IR) injury.
results_summary: Se@PSN demonstrated strong ROS scavenging abilities, enhanced GPX4 levels to inhibit ferroptosis, improved mitochondrial respiratory complex expression, and reduced myocardial loss, inflammation, and fibrosis following IR injury. It showed superior therapeutic efficacy compared to PSN alone.
population_specificity: Cardiomyocytes and myocardial IR injury models (specific human or animal population not detailed in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and evaluate silica-coated SPION clusters as potential theranostic agents, focusing on synthesis efficiency, magnetization properties, and drug-loading capabilities.
results_summary: The study found that microwave-assisted synthesis reduced time and energy requirements for SPION clusters while improving magnetization-to-particle ratios. Silica coating methods provided high homogeneity, and the material demonstrated successful loading and release of a model molecule, indicating potential as a theranostic agent.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro or preclinical study implied).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a hypoxia-responsive nanomaterial using mesoporous silica nanoparticles for controlled doxorubicin release in hypoxic tumor environments.
results_summary: The study demonstrated that the nitroreductase-responsive silica nanocarrier effectively released doxorubicin under bioreductive conditions, showing potential for treating hypoxic tumors in vitro using A549 cells.
population_specificity: A549 cells (a human lung adenocarcinoma cell line known to express nitroreductase).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether incorporating a silica aerogel coating could enhance the flame retardancy and mechanical properties of rigid polyurethane foam (RPUF) composites.
results_summary: The silica aerogel coating significantly improved flame retardancy, increasing the LOI to 25.3%, delaying ignition time, and reducing heat release and smoke production, while maintaining thermal insulation and enhancing compressive strength.
population_specificity: Not specified (material science study, not human or animal subjects).
study_duration: Not specified (experimental study without defined intervention period).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of mesoporous silica nanoparticles (MSNs) as nanocarriers for gene therapy, focusing on their delivery capabilities for nucleic acids like siRNA, DNA, and CRISPR-Cas systems.
results_summary: The study found that MSNs are a promising platform for targeted gene delivery due to their structural features, stability, and controlled release properties, with potential applications in theranostics and personalized treatment strategies.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of existing research)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the photocatalytic, antibacterial, and antioxidant properties of silica-based nanocomposites (C-SiO₂, Ag-SiO₂, and ZnO-SiO₂) for potential environmental and health applications.
results_summary: The study found that ZnO-SiO₂ and Ag-SiO₂ nanocomposites exhibited strong antimicrobial activity (80-88% against E. coli and Pseudomonas), antioxidant scavenging efficiencies (57.8-71%), and photocatalytic degradation rates (45-75% for p-nitroanilines), outperforming C-SiO₂ nanoparticles.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study on bacterial strains and chemical degradation).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a novel multi-step pre-treatment process to efficiently fractionate and valorize silica from rice husk, avoiding environmental harm while maximizing yield and purity.
results_summary: The study achieved high separation efficiency (>97%) for hemicellulose, lignin, and silica, with silica recovery at 77.5 wt% in the third treatment step, demonstrating effective valorization of rice husk components.
population_specificity: Not applicable (in vitro study using rice husk biomass).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the anticancer effects of Egyptian cobra Naja haje venom, both alone and in combination with nanoparticles, on triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) in vivo.
results_summary: The study found that venom treatment significantly improved inflammatory cytokine and tumor marker levels, increased expression of tumor-suppressor genes, and enhanced apoptosis and necrosis in TNBC. The combination with nanoparticles showed promising results in enhancing these effects.
population_specificity: Experimental rats (10 per group) with induced TNBC.
effective_dosage: Higher dose (1/5 LD50) and lower dose (1/20 LD50) of crude venom.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of sugarcane ash-derived silica nanoparticles (SAD SiNPs) on human kidney proximal convoluted tubule cells and identify potential toxicity mechanisms.
results_summary: SAD SiNPs caused mitochondrial dysfunction, increased reactive oxygen species, and disrupted redox signaling, suggesting a glycolytic and fibrotic shift consistent with chronic kidney disease pathology. Pristine SiNPs showed minimal effects.
population_specificity: Human kidney proximal convoluted tubule (HK-2) cells in vitro.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate different immobilization strategies for laccase on amino-functionalized silica to develop efficient and stable biocatalysts for hospital wastewater treatment.
results_summary: Covalent immobilization using glutaraldehyde (GLA) under optimized conditions produced a biocatalyst with superior stability and catalytic potential, effectively removing phenolic compounds and trace organic contaminants (TrOCs) from hospital wastewater. The immobilized laccase showed comparable catalytic parameters to free laccase, indicating retained enzymatic activity.
population_specificity: Hospital wastewater (real non-treated effluent spiked with contaminants).
effective_dosage: Laccase loading: 10 kU/L, pH 5, temperature: 5 °C, immobilization time: 8 h, GLA amount: 100 mM.
study_duration: Immobilization time: 8 hours (intervention duration not specified beyond this).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a superhydrophobic/superoleophilic chitosan-based composite incorporating silica nanoparticles for selective oil absorption and efficient oil/water separation.
results_summary: The optimized SH-SiO2@3CNTs/CS composite exhibited superhydrophobicity, superoleophilicity, high chemical stability, and excellent resistance to high temperature and friction, achieving an oil absorption capacity of up to 18.24 times its own weight and a separation efficiency exceeding 97% for oil/water mixtures and water-in-oil emulsions.
population_specificity: Not applicable (material science study, no human or animal subjects).
effective_dosage: Not applicable (material composition optimized, not a dosage study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the mechanism by which Silica nanoparticles (SiNPs) cause neuroblast injury and cell death in SH-SY5Y cells.
results_summary: SiNPs reduced cell survival, induced oxidative stress (ROS and Ca2+ overload), impaired mitochondrial function, and activated PARP and caspase pathways, leading to apoptosis. Inhibitors of these pathways (Olaparib and Z-VAD) significantly mitigated these effects.
population_specificity: SH-SY5Y neuroblastoma cells (in vitro model).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate silica-coated gold nanoparticles (AuMS) as a biocompatible tool for tracking mesenchymal stem cells (MSCs) in vivo and assess their impact on MSC immunomodulatory functions.
results_summary: The study found that AuMS effectively labeled MSCs for in vivo tracking up to 72 hours post-administration without altering their immunomodulatory or proliferation capabilities. AuMS localization was observed in the liver, spleen, and lung.
population_specificity: Translational ovine model of preterm birth.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the research progress of hollow mesoporous silica nanoparticles (HMSNs) as drug carriers, focusing on their microstructure, surface modification, and factors affecting drug delivery and efficacy.
results_summary: The study found that HMSNs exhibit high efficiency, targeting, and controlled release properties, making them promising for medical therapy, especially in cancer treatment. Factors like preparation method, particle characteristics, and external environment significantly influence drug delivery and efficacy.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of existing studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of silica gel-immobilized alunite (Sg@Aln) in removing nickel ions (Ni2+) from contaminated water through adsorption.
results_summary: The study found that Sg@Aln effectively adsorbed Ni2+ with a maximum removal efficiency of 89.11% under optimal conditions (2 g/L adsorbent, pH 5.0, 10 min contact time). The adsorption process followed the Langmuir isotherm and pseudo-second-order kinetics, indicating favorable and spontaneous adsorption.
population_specificity: Contaminated aqueous media (not human or animal subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a lipid membrane-immobilized monolithic silica (LMiMS) column for HPLC analysis to study interactions between lipid membranes and nucleic acids.
results_summary: The LMiMS column effectively imitated temperature-dependent properties of lipid membranes, revealing that membrane interactions with oligonucleotides were influenced by phase state and salt concentration, with stronger interactions above the phase transition temperature.
population_specificity: Not applicable (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the relationship between fluorescent defects and laser-induced damage on fused silica optics, and how surface treatments like dynamic chemical etching (DCE) affect damage probability.
results_summary: The study found that laser-induced damage probability depends on fluorescent defect type, brightness, and radiation flux, with DCE treatment reducing damage probability from 25% to 6% at 12 J/cm². Most damage precursors lacked photoluminescent characteristics, and DCE enhanced non-photoluminescent traits.
population_specificity: Fused silica optics (not human or biological).
effective_dosage: Radiation flux levels of 12 J/cm² and 20 J/cm².

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of mesoporous silica nanoparticles (MSNs) in targeted drug delivery, cancer diagnosis, and the development of advanced biosensors and stimuli-responsive drug delivery platforms.
results_summary: The study found that MSNs enhance therapeutic effectiveness through targeted drug delivery, high drug-loading capacity, and controlled release, while minimizing adverse effects on healthy cells. It also highlighted MSNs' potential in cancer diagnosis and responsiveness to various internal and external stimuli.
population_specificity: Not specified (focused on in vitro and preclinical applications).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to optimize the extraction and preparation conditions of hydrophobic silica aerogels (HSA) from rice husk ash using machine learning and to investigate how preparation conditions and heat treatment affect properties like porosity and hydrophobicity.
results_summary: The study found that the decision tree regression model best predicted water glass extraction rates and modulus. HSA produced with nitric acid as a catalyst achieved superhydrophobicity (contact angle of 159.5°), but higher concentrations of hydrophobic modifiers reduced porosity. HSA maintained hydrophobicity up to 500°C, but pore structure collapsed at higher temperatures, with complete loss of hydrophobicity and severe damage at 700°C.
population_specificity: Not specified (laboratory study, no human or animal subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether quaternary ammonium chitosan-modified mesoporous silica nanoparticles (MSN-NH2-CFP@HACC) could effectively target and treat intracellular Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) infections.
results_summary: The study found that MSN-NH2-CFP@HACC nanoparticles were efficiently internalized by macrophages, showed accelerated drug release in acidic environments, and exhibited enhanced antibacterial properties, effectively suppressing MRSA proliferation and intracellular escape. Additionally, HACC coating improved bacterial capture and reduced resistance by disrupting bacterial membranes and inhibiting β-lactamase activity.
population_specificity: Murine model of MRSA bacteremia (mice).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the adsorption properties of a novel ZnAl-LDHs/SiO2 (ZA/SiO2) composite for removing toxic metal ions (Cu(II) and Cr(VI)) from water.
results_summary: The ZA/SiO2 composite demonstrated significantly improved adsorption capacity for Cu(II) (158 mg·g⁻¹) and Cr(VI) (176 mg·g⁻¹), outperforming ZnAl-LDHs alone. The primary removal mechanisms involved intercalation and ion exchange for Cr(VI) and isomorphic substitution for Cu(II).
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study on water treatment).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Fe3O4-vMSN-FA nanocomposites loaded with Lenvatinib could effectively target liver cancer cells and enhance anti-tumor effects.
results_summary: The study found that Fe3O4-vMSN-FA nanocomposites successfully delivered Lenvatinib, demonstrated good stability and biocompatibility, and significantly reduced tumor volume in HepG2 cells and mice without causing obvious organ damage.
population_specificity: HepG2 liver cancer cells and mice with hepatocellular carcinoma.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop an activatable photosensitizer (aPS) using silica-based nanostructures for enhanced antibacterial and anticancer applications.
results_summary: The study demonstrated that silica-based nanostructures (DHU-MSNs) effectively combined photodynamic therapy with chemotherapy, showing synergistic antibacterial action and efficacy against spinal metastases of lung cancer.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro or preclinical study implied).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the diagnostic and therapeutic applications of mesoporous silica nanoparticles (MSNs) for liver diseases, particularly hepatocellular carcinoma.
results_summary: The study found that MSNs have significant diagnostic capabilities in techniques like MRI, NIR fluorescence imaging, and PAI, and serve as effective drug delivery carriers for liver disease treatment. Toxicity studies were summarized, but specific safety outcomes were not detailed.
population_specificity: Liver disease patients, particularly those with hepatocellular carcinoma.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential of silica nanoparticles (SiNPs) as a vehicle for targeted anti-cancer drug delivery, focusing on their synthesis, functionalization, and therapeutic applications.
results_summary: The study found that SiNPs offer advantages such as high drug loading capacity, controlled release, and targeted delivery, which enhance therapeutic efficacy and reduce systemic toxicity in cancer treatment. The review highlights SiNPs' versatility in delivering chemotherapeutic agents, photosensitizers, and nucleic acids.
population_specificity: Not specified (review article, not a clinical study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a rapid, cost-effective nanocoated whole-cell biocatalyst (G19A-GDH@O-Silica) for efficient preparation of (S)-NEMCA-HEPE, a key intermediate in (S)-Rivastigmine synthesis.
results_summary: The silica-nanocoated G19A-GDH@O-Silica demonstrated excellent conversion (99%) and enantiomeric excess (99%) for (S)-NEMCA-HEPE, with improved thermal, pH, and storage stability, and maintained 76.3% conversion after 11 reuse cycles.
population_specificity: In vitro enzymatic/cellular system (not human or animal study).
study_duration: Reaction completed within 40 minutes; stability tested over multiple reuse cycles.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the adsorption performance of a novel silica-based material (Si-MPTS-IL) for removing Coomassie Brilliant Blue (CBB) from wastewater.
